tossups.question: This character tells a boy that two girls will follow him, and he will marry “the poor one first and the rich one by and by.” This man believes that his hairy chest and arms mean he is destined for wealth. A rattlesnake bites this man on the leg after another character puts a dead snake by him while he is sleeping. This man owns a five-cent piece that can supposedly cure illness and a magical ox’s hairball. He believes another character to be a ghost when he reencounters him on an (*) island, and he shields that boy from seeing a dead body in a wrecked houseboat. This character tells his travelling companion his plans to have abolitionists kidnap his family, and he runs away from his owner, Miss Watson. For 10 points, name this Mark Twain character, an escaped slave who accompanies the title character of The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn.

According to an early 20th century theory of the Jehovah’s Witnesses, one member of this group is likely the throne of God. In Kiowa legend, Devils Tower was formed when a rock saved this group from being attacked by a bear. In one system, a member of this group is ashamed and hides herself because she married the mortal Sisyphus, while another member was the mother of (*) Hermes. After they were turned to doves by Zeus, or after they killed themselves out of grief for the dead Hyades, this group, whose members were pursued by Orion in life, were placed in the heavens.For 10 points, name this group that in Greek myth consists of the daughters of Pleione and Atlas, who were turned into a cluster of stars.

E.H. Dyer established the United States’ first successful mill for this good, which prompted Arthur Stayner to restart the Mormon Church’s attempts to build an industry in this commodity after the failure of the Desert Manufacturing Company. During World War I, the U.S. sent in Marines to prop up the government of Mario García Menocal on the pretext of supporting wartime production of this commodity. The Reciprocity Treaty of 1875 granted the United States a naval base at (*) Pearl Harbor in exchange for lowering tariffs on this commodity dominated by the “Big Five” companies in the Kingdom of Hawaii. Colonial New England manufacturers distilled molasses produced from this commodity for export to Europe in the triangle trade. For 10 points, name this sweetener extracted from beets or cane.

The timing of this process is predicted using the fibronectin test. This process will occur spontaneously if Bishop’s score is high. A complication of this process can be treated, in succession, with the McRoberts maneuver, the Woods maneuver, or the Zavanelli maneuver. During this process, the station changes from negative 3 to positive 2. A positive GBS culture indicates the need for penicillin prophylaxis during this process. Terbutaline and other tocolytics are used to delay this process. Magnesium sulfate prophylaxis is used during this process for patients with (*) pre-eclampsia. This process can be induced using misoprostol or oxytocin. Arrest of this process is an indication for cesarean section. For 10 points, name this process, during which the cervix dilates to 10 centimeters before the placenta and fetus are expelled from the uterus.
tossups.answer: labor [accept equivalents of giving birth; do NOT accept C-section or cesarean section; prompt on “water-breaking”, “rupture of membranes”, “pregnancy”, “contractions”]
tossups.answer_formatted: labor [accept equivalents of giving birth; do NOT accept C-section or cesarean section; prompt on water-breaking”, “rupture of membranes”, “pregnancy”, “contractions]

tossups.question: In the fourth movement of a string quartet in E-flat major by this composer, a restatement of the opening theme is abruptly cut off when the tempo switches from presto in 6/8 to adagio in 2/4 for four bars, then back. That movement unusually ends with a pianissimo restatement of the opening two bars following a grand pause. He composed over 120 trios for viola, cello, and baryton (“BAR-i-tawn”), the latter of which was the preferred instrument of his longtime patron but is rarely played today. This composer’s Opus (*) 76, No. 3 string quartet reuses the tune from his hymn “Gott erhalte Franz den Kaiser,” (“gott er-halt-uh Franz den kai-ser”) and that melody is used today for the German national anthem. This composer wrote his “Joke,” “Fifths,” and “Emperor” quartets while in the service of the Esterházy family. For 10 points, name this Austrian composer known as the “Father of the String Quartet.”

Zia-ul-Haq authorized the ISI to sponsor Kashmiri insurgents in an operation named for this man. This man was falsely attributed the quote, “Peasant, the master will no longer feed from your hunger,” to promote the agrarian reforms of Juan Velasco’s regime. This husband of Micaela Bastidas kidnapped Antonio de Arriaga, the corregidor of Tinta, and won the Battle of Sangarará. Under the leadership of Raúl Sendic, an insurgent group in Uruguay named for this man kidnapped advisor (*) Dan Mitrione. Another revolutionary movement named for this man stormed the Japanese embassy during the presidency of Alberto Fujimori. Viceroy Toledo executed a man of this name who had ruled Vilcabamba in Cusco. For 10 points, give this name of an Incan revolutionary who inspired the name of Afeni Shakur’s son.
tossups.answer: Tupac Amaru [or Tupac Amaru I; or Tupac Amaru II; or the Túpac Amaru Revolutionary Movement; or Tupac Amaru Shakur; or Jose Gabriel Condorcanqui Noguera; prompt on Tupamaros; prompt on Tupac or Amaru]
tossups.answer_formatted: Tupac Amaru [or Tupac Amaru I; or Tupac Amaru II; or the Túpac Amaru Revolutionary Movement; or Tupac Amaru Shakur; or Jose Gabriel Condorcanqui Noguera; prompt on Tupamaros; prompt on Tupac or Amaru]

tossups.question: This substance is used as a solvent when performing FTIR on amides, because it lacks an absorption band that overlaps with the amide band. Hydrogen sulfide is circulated in a temperature gradient to produce this compound in the Geib-Spevack process. TMSP dissolved in this substance is a common NMR standard. Dissolving a protein in this substance, then subjecting it to mass spectrometry, is a common method of finding exposed residues. Using this compound as a NMR solvent removes peaks from (*) labile protons belonging to hydroxyl groups. Nuclear reactors that use this substance as a moderator eliminate the need to enrich uranium. This substance has an atomic mass of 20. For 10 points, name this substance, also known as deuterium oxide.
tossups.answer: heavy water [or deuterium oxide; or heavy water; or D2O; do not prompt or accept “water” or “H2O”]
tossups.answer_formatted: heavy water [or deuterium oxide; or heavy water; or D2O; do not prompt or accept “water” or “H2O”]

tossups.question: One of these events created a media frenzy in Zeitoun, Egypt following the Six-Day War after Farouk Atwa thought he saw someone attempt suicide. A feast day on August 5th celebrates the dedication of a church where one of these events took place during which snow fell on the Esquiline Hill in Rome under the pontificate of Liberius. A statement taken from one of these events was often interpreted as an end to communism in Russia; that statement was revealed to St. Lucia during that event of this type. Clean water which healed the sick was discovered as a result of one of these events by (*) St. Bernadette in Lourdes. The three secrets of Fatima were revealed at one of these events, another of which Juan Diego observed at Tepeyac Hill. Our Lady of Guadalupe commemorates, for 10 points, what mysterious events regarding Jesus’ mother coming to earth?
tossups.answer: Marian apparitions [or apparitions of Mary; accept synonyms or similar descriptions for apparition like appearance; prompt on just apparition]
tossups.answer_formatted: Marian apparitions [or apparitions of Mary; accept synonyms or similar descriptions for apparition like appearance; prompt on just apparition]
acceptable: similar descriptions for apparition like appearance

tossups.question: This company decided to place its logo on the jerseys of Club América after discovering that they were the victors of the 2015 CONCACAF Champions League. The founder of this company declared ‘our biggest enemy is ourselves’ in a BBC interview at Davos in 2015. Early in 2019, Serbian politician Aleksandar Vučić (“VOO-chich”) contracted this company to install one thousand cameras with (*) facial recognition software in Belgrade. In December 2018, the Chief Financial Officer of this company was arrested in Vancouver on behalf of the United States. BT opted to discontinue use of this company’s product in the “core” of its service one week after New Zealand barred the use of this company’s equipment in its 5G networks. For 10 points, name this tech giant under international scrutiny for its close connections to the Chinese government.

One character in this work causes a seat to awkwardly creak when he gets up to help a woman detach her shawl from a table. This work’s title character justifies visits to brothels by saying "it was all done with clean hands, in clean linen, with French phrases" and has a life "most simple and most ordinary and therefore most terrible." That title character of this work thinks the syllogism “Caius (“KYE-us”) is a man, men are (*) mortal, therefore Caius is mortal” is correct as applied to Caius, but not himself. This story begins with the title character's colleagues planning what promotions they might receive. That title character has the servant Gerasim hold his legs, and he screams for three days before hearing someone say, "It is finished!" This work’s title character is married to Praskovya and injures himself while hanging curtains. For 10 points, name this Leo Tolstoy novella about the death of the title judge.
tossups.answer: The Death of Ivan Ilyich [or Smert’ Ivána Ilyichá]
tossups.answer_formatted: The Death of Ivan Ilyich [or Smert’ Ivána Ilyichá]

tossups.question: Neumaier developed a modification to one algorithm for this task, which relies on a running compensation value to repeatedly correct the output. For a holomorphic function with a certain bound on its error, Watson’s theorem guarantees the uniqueness of one version of this operation. Kahan names a balancing algorithm for this task. A piece of hardware that carries out this task can be chained together such that the carry from one (*) ripples to the next. Borel names a version of this operation. This operation is not performed on free indices in Einstein notation. Narrowing the width of the subinterval in a version of this operation named for Riemann is used to define the integral. In another context, this operation can be carried out using the parallelogram rule or the tail-to-tip method. For 10 points, name this operation, which, when repeated, is symbolized by an uppercase sigma.
tossups.answer: summation [or adding; accept Borel summation or vector summation]

tossups.question: James M. Buchanan and Richard E. Wagner's book Democracy in [this condition] extends the timescale of Robert Barro's application of Ricardian equivalence to a government undergoing this condition. One theory about this condition suggests that a negative trade balance is intimately linked to it since fiscal stimulus results in increased imports; that current accounts shortfall is therefore a (*) "twin" of this condition. Unlike the American federal government, which can allay this condition through issuance of sovereign debt, most state governments have balanced budget amendments and are thus forced to avoid this condition, which is expected to reach $1 trillion in 2020. For 10 points, name this condition whereby a nation's expenditures exceed revenues, whose accumulation results in the national debt.
tossups.answer: the federal budget deficits [prompt on budget shortfall before "budget" is mentioned; prompt on debt until mentioned]
tossups.answer_formatted: the federal budget deficits [prompt on budget shortfall before "budget" is mentioned; prompt on debt until mentioned]

tossups.question: Note to moderator: Read answer line carefully. OZET trained the impoverished among these people in agriculture, while Komzet settled them on farms. Around the 1910s, Jacob Schiff financed the emigration of these people to Galveston, Texas instead of Ellis Island. Khappers kidnapped young boys of this ethnicity on behalf of local qahals in order to fill recruitment quotas for cantonist schools. The Pulitzer Prize-winning (*) The Fixer is based on one of these people acquitted for murder in the Beilis trial. The Yevsektsiya sought to carry the communist revolution to these people, who were the subject of the discriminatory non-German May Laws. After 1791, these people were confined to living in the Pale of Settlement by Catherine the Great. For 10 points, name these people who were driven out of imperial Warsaw and Kiev by 19th-century pogroms.
tossups.answer: Russian Jews [or Soviet Jews; prompt on Polish Jews or Ukrainian Jews or Jews with “living in which empire?”; prompt on American Jews with “migrating from which country?”]
tossups.answer_formatted: Russian Jews [or Soviet Jews; prompt on Polish Jews or Ukrainian Jews or Jews with “living in which empire?; prompt on American Jews with “migrating from which country?]
promptable: American Jews with “migrating from which country?

tossups.question: It’s not Federico Gonzaga, but a camarino in the Palazzo Te is named for this author, who also inspired an illusionistic Giulio Romano fresco there. Seven large canvases based on this author’s work were commissioned by Philip II. A sensuously reclining woman is enveloped by a cloud through which a face can be seen in a series by Correggio illustrating this author. A man reaches out in front of a large pink robe while a woman is protected by a dark skinned servant and a snarling lapdog in a (*) poesie illustrating this author’s work. It’s not Catullus, but a painting depicting this author’s work shows a man wrestling snakes as a god jumps from a chariot drawn by two cheetahs. That painting based on his work is Titian’s Bacchus and Ariadne. For 10 points, Italian Renaissance artists often painted mythological scenes based on what Roman author’s Metamorphoses?

Beams of these particles used for spectroscopy are divided into low-momentum “Arizona” or “surface” beams and high-momentum “decay” beams. These particles are embedded into a target and the resulting decay products are measured in that form of spin spectroscopy. This particle’s antiparticle may capture an electron and form an exotic atom with an ionization energy within 1% of normal hydrogen. The large reduced mass of (*) hydrogen atoms containing this particle allows nuclei to come much closer together, which makes this particle a potential catalyst for cold nuclear fusion. This particle decays to an electron, an electron antineutrino, and a namesake neutrino, with a half-life of 2.2 microseconds. For 10 points, name this lepton with the spin and charge of an electron, but with a mass between that of an electron and a tau.

In one short story by this author, a character counts his head, his wife's head, and the heads of three of his four children as his "five inestimable blessings" with which he escaped a war. In another of this author’s stories, Reginald gains respect for female soldiers after Gladys searches his van, but is angry when he sees her wearing a dress. This author of “Girls at War” created the (*) bike-courier Jonathan, who has his "egg-rasher" money taken but is not bothered because "Nothing puzzles God." In another short story by this author, the young headmaster Mr. Obi plants hedges across the title structure connecting a graveyard with a shrine, angering the villagers. One character by this author of "Dead Men's Path" and "Civil Peace" breaks the Week of Peace and kills his adopted son Ikemefuna. For 10 points, name this author who wrote about Okonkwo in Things Fall Apart.

In a 2010 paper partially titled for this position, Jonathan Schaffer argued for this philosophical view by demonstrating the metaphysical possibility of a substance called “gunk.” In his paper “Consciousness and its Place in Nature,” David Chalmers advocates for a position he calls “panprotopsychism” or the “type-F” variety of this philosophical position. In books like The Analysis of Mind and The Analysis of Matter, Bertrand Russell espoused a variant of this philosophical view which is typically known as the “neutral” variant. The paper (*) “Mental Events,” argues that “all events are physical” but that “mental phenomena can[not] be given purely physical explanation,” a variety of this view held by Donald Davidson and known as its “anomalous” variant. For 10 points, identify this philosophical position which holds that everything that exists is ultimately made up of one kind of substance.

For one shot, this artist was only permitted to use three flashbulbs, but lost one to the heat and moisture and forgot to pull the slide on another, leaving only one flash usable. Aerial photographs by this artist include one in which a DC-4 flies over Manhattan. Though not Annie Leibovitz, this artist is shown seated on one of the sculpted eagles of the Chrysler Building in another photo. This artist took a shot of Montana’s Fort Peck Dam which appeared on the first cover of (*) LIFE magazine following its 1936 relaunch. Together with her onetime husband Erskine Caldwell, she documented the lives of sharecroppers in the Deep South in the book You Have Seen Their Faces. She was the first female photographer to cover World War II. For 10 points, name this American photojournalist who photographed Mahatma Gandhi at his spinning wheel.

Helen Vendler claims this poem's subject "speaks the only language that [the author] can invent… adequate to an eternal being." T. S. Eliot dissed this poem's closing line, which is uttered by “a friend of man” “in midst of other woe” as "a serious blemish on a beautiful poem.” This poem repeats the word "happy" six times before addressing "a burning forehead, and a parching tongue" caused by "all breathing human passion." This poem describes a "little town by river or sea shore" which lies (*) empty. This work’s title “foster child of silence and slow time" makes the narrator ask "What men or gods are these?...What wild ecstasy?" This work’s title “unravished bride of quietness” prompts the statements "Heard melodies are sweet, but those unheard are sweeter” and “Beauty is truth, truth beauty.” For 10 points, name this ode about a piece of classical pottery by John Keats.

A prince of this house pioneered volley fire at the Battle of Nieuwpoort (“NEW-port”) and brainstormed a series of fortifications known as the Water Line. King Frederick Wilhelm II of Prussia organized a 1787 intervention to support the rule of this house after the arrest of his sister by republicans of the Patriot movement. After his ouster, a prince of this house wrote the Kew Letters to urge his countrymen to resist the (*) Batavian Republic. A fraternal order of Ulster unionists takes its name from this house, which produced a king of England who took power in the Glorious Revolution. Balthasar Gerard assassinated the first prince of this house, Stadtholder William the Silent, during the Eighty Years’ War. For 10 points, name this royal house of the Netherlands, which shares its name with the Dutch national color.
tossups.answer: House of Orange-Nassau [prompt on House of Nassau]

bonuses.leadin: One myth from this country involves a goddess being slain by her husband after she spits out various animals into the ocean and forest respectively. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this country, whose myths include gods such as Uzume, Fūjin, and Tsukuyomi in Shintoism .
This mythical person was the first emperor of Japan. This man was assisted by a three-legged bird on his journey to capture Yamato.
This god was the great-grandfather of Emperor Jimmu. Under the orders of Amaterasu, this god brought a jewel, mirror, and sword to Japan in order to restore it.

bonuses.leadin: This article opens with a quote from Deuteronomy in which the addressee is implored to remember a time “in the land of Egypt.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this 2014 Ta-Nehisi Coates article in which he examined the differences in black and white poverty and home ownership while arguing for the titular concept.
“The Case for Reparations” was published in this magazine currently edited by Jeffrey Goldberg and named for the large body of water near the town where it was founded, Boston.
This second-oldest continuously published literary magazine in the U.S. underwent significant changes in the 1980s under the leadership of editor Lewis Lapham.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about physical deformations in materials. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this quantity that measures a material’s stiffness. For a linearly elastic material, it equals stress divided by strain. This “modulus” is named after a British physicist who also did the double slit experiment.
This quantity equals the negative ratio of transverse strain to longitudinal strain, and describes how materials expand in the direction perpendicular to a compressive force.

The true strain of a deformed material is measured with respect to the deformed cross-sectional area, in contrast to this other kind of strain, which is measured relative to the initial cross-sectional area.

bonuses.leadin: “‘God save Ireland!’ said the heroes / ‘God save Ireland’ said they all.” Answer the following about Irish rebel music. For 10 points each:
answers: Black and Tans [or The Royal Irish Constabulary Special Reserve; prompt on Royal Irish Constabulary]
Theobald Wolfe Tone [or the Wolfe Tones]
parts: Dominic Behan’s song “Come Out Ye [these people]” asks them to tell their wives “...how the IRA made you run like hell away / from the green and lovely lanes of Killeshandra.” This notoriously brutal auxiliary force opened fire at a Gaelic football match at Croke Park.

A prolific Irish rebel music band is named for this revolutionary, who helped found the United Irishmen. This Protestant was executed for leading the 1798 Irish Rebellion with the support of the French First Republic.
The sporting anthem “The Fields of Athenry” describes a man shipped to the Australian penal colony for having “stole Trevelyan’s corn” during the 1840s famine caused by the failure of this crop.
answers_formatted: Black and Tans [or The Royal Irish Constabulary Special Reserve; prompt on Royal Irish Constabulary]
acceptable: The Royal Irish Constabulary Special Reserve

bonuses.leadin: This medication is often used in combination with losartan to treat hypertension. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this class of diuretics with a bicyclic molecular structure that contains adjacent sulfur and nitrogen atoms. HCTZ is one of these drugs.
Thiazides primarily work on the sodium-chloride symporter on this part of the kidney responsible for final sodium reabsorption before reaching the collecting duct. It occurs after the loop of Henle.

Thiazides can also be used to treat kidney stones caused by accumulation of this ion. This ion’s levels in the blood are increased by parathyroid hormone triggering breakdown of bone, and vitamin D helps absorb it.

bonuses.leadin: This composer wrote a concerto in G major for the unusual combination of two mandolins. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this Italian composer, who wrote brief poems as footnotes to the violin concertos which comprise his series The Four Seasons.
The outer movements of Vivaldi’s Double Concerto for Two Mandolins are structured around these repeating sections, which were commonly used as instrumental refrains in baroque operas and concertos.

The harmony in Vivaldi’s concertos is sustained by this type of accompaniment, which was ubiquitous in the baroque era and typically consisted of an instrumental bass line written in figured bass notation, so a keyboard or lute player could realize chords above it.

bonuses.leadin: These things are characterized by their ability to “produce various sensations in us,” and they are held to do so “by the operation of insensible particles.” For 10 points each:
answers: secondary qualities [do not prompt on or accept partial answers]
parts: Identify these concepts outlined in An Essay Concerning Human Understanding. They are said to include colors, sounds, and tastes.
The division of material qualities into primary and secondary types was described by this philosopher in the second book of his Essay Concerning Human Understanding.

Locke holds that since an exact collection of secondary qualities would not give us the essence of a thing, complex ideas of substances have this feature. Locke used this term to refer to ideas that do not perfectly represent their archetypes.
answers_formatted: secondary qualities [do not prompt on or accept partial answers]

bonuses.leadin: This poem describes dancers who “seem not to believe in their own happiness,” and it opens with the line “Your soul is a chosen landscape / where roam charming masques.” For 10 points each:
answers: Poèmes saturniens [or Saturnine Poems or Saturnian Poems or Poems under Saturn]
parts: Name this poem, which describes a song that “blends with the moonlight, / With the sad and beautiful moonlight.”
This French author and lover of Arthur Rimbaud (“ram-BOUW”) wrote “Clair de Lune.”

Melancholia and Paysages tristes (“pay-ZAWJ TREEST”) are two sections of this first poetry collection by Verlaine. Its prologue says “Every soul depends upon a star” and dedicates the book to those born under a “planet / to the necromancer dear.”
answers_formatted: Poèmes saturniens [or Saturnine Poems or Saturnian Poems or Poems under Saturn]

bonuses.leadin: Algeria has hosted thousands of refugees from this ethnic group for decades in Tindouf Province, where this ethnic group’s namesake government-in-exile is headquartered. For 10 points each:
answers: Polisario Front [or Frente Polisario; or FRELISARIO]
parts: Name this ethnic group that has fought for independence in the Western Sahara. This Hassaniya Arabic-speaking ethnic group descends from the Yemeni Beni Hassan tribe and local Berbers.
This organization proclaimed the Sahrawi Arab Democratic Republic and fought a war in Western Sahara to control the territory after the Spanish withdrawal in 1976.

In the 1975 Madrid Accords, Mauritania agreed to split Western Sahara with this North African kingdom, which built a 2,700 kilometer sand berm to separate its “Southern Provinces” from Polisario Front-territory.

bonuses.leadin: A mosaic depicting this scene is found on the ceiling of the apse of Sicily’s Cefalu (“CHAY-fah-loo”) Cathedral. For 10 points each:
answers: the Holy Trinity [accept The Hospitality of Abraham; or any answer mentioning angels and Abraham, as that is what is actually depicted in Rublev’s version]
parts: Name this scene that takes up the center of a deesis (“DEE-es-is”). This scene shows Jesus holding the New Testament with his left hand and making a blessing gesture symbolizing the letters IC XC with his right hand.

The image of Christ Pantocrator appears in many of these religious artworks that are venerated in the Eastern Orthodox Church. They were destroyed during two periods in Byzantine history in a movement named after them.

Andrei Rublev’s icon of this subject is at the Tretyakov Gallery and has a cup at its center. An illusionistic barrel vault frames the central group in Masaccio's version of this subject, which has a memento mori at the bottom.
answers_formatted: the Holy Trinity [accept The Hospitality of Abraham; or any answer mentioning angels or Abraham, as that is what is actually depicted in Rublev’s version]
acceptable: Abraham, as that is what is actually depicted in Rublev’s version

bonuses.leadin: In compounds with this geometry, the t-sub-2g orbitals split higher than the e-sub-g orbitals. For 10 points each:
answers: gerade and ungerade [or g and u]
parts: Name this molecular geometry exemplified by hemiacetals and methane. The angle between bonds in this geometry is about 109.4.

Molecules with octahedral geometries also have d-orbitals split into two levels, but they undergo this effect more strongly in order to break the degeneracy of their d orbitals. In this effect, bonds along the z-axis are elongated.
The Jahn-Teller effect breaks symmetry to allow transitions between two states of the same parity with respect to an inversion center. Those states are given these two names, name both.

bonuses.leadin: There’s nothing like a dance that tells you how to do the moves--except when the dance was also made up for a TV show or movie. Answer the following about these fictional dances, for 10 points each:
parts: In “Threat Level Midnight,” an episode of “The Office,” Michael’s cinematic spy alter ego leads the gang in this dance, whose moves include “you meet new friends, you tie some yarn, and that’s how you do” this dance.

On this TV show, the titular character shows everyone how to do a dance in which you “twist yourself around and give a great big lunge” while dancing alongside Pearl, a whale who in that episode is the prom date to this show’s titular character.
The cast of The Rocky Horror Picture Show performs this line dance, which is “just a jump to the left, and then a step to the right”.

bonuses.leadin: This character’s estranged father mistakenly thinks her fiancé Adolphus Cusins is his son, and this character and her father make a deal to visit each others’ place of work. For 10 points each:
answers: Barbara Undershaft [or Major Barbara; prompt on Undershaft]
parts: Name this character, who becomes disillusioned with the Salvation Army after they accept a large donation of money from her father’s arms manufacturing business.
Major Barbara is the title character of a play written by this author of Arms and the Man and Pygmalion.

Barbara’s mother Lady Britomart contacts her estranged husband for money after discussing the family’s finances with this other character, who is later disinherited from his father’s business because he is not a foundling.

bonuses.leadin: Denied a spot in Whittier College’s elite Franklin Society, this man founded the Orthogonian Society for students from poorer backgrounds like himself. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this candidate who debated the wealthy JFK in the nation’s first televised presidential debate. This politician proclaimed his innocence in the Checkers speech and resigned the presidency after Watergate.

This historian of American conservatism uses the Orthogonian-Franklin metaphor to stress Nixon’s hatred for elites in his biography Nixonland. This historian chronicled Nixon’s fall and Reagan’s rise in The Invisible Bridge.
Perlstein’s first book Before the Storm discusses the rise of this arch-conservative. This senator laid the groundwork for the Reagan Revolution in his 1960 book The Conscience of a Conservative.

bonuses.leadin: In 2013, this dancer’s career was nearly cut short when she suffered a leg injury in a performance of The Firebird. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this ballerina, who in 2015 became the first African-American woman to be named principal dancer of American Ballet Theatre.

In 2018, Copeland took to social media to defend herself from critics who called her an “embarrassment” for omitting steps in her dual role as Odette and Odile in a performance of this ballet with music by Tchaikovsky.
In the sequence for which Copeland was ridiculed, Odile is required to execute 32 of these turns, which usually consist of a pirouette along with a whip of a raised leg.

bonuses.leadin: Mythical and sacred cetacean time! For ten points each:
parts: In the Hindu tradition, Makara is occasionally depicted as a river dolphin ridden by the divine personification of the Ganges, Ganga. Ganga was married to this king of Hastinapura until she left him after killing 7 of their children.
The fingers of a goddess from this myth system were chopped off and became seals and whales after her father Anguta tried to throw her off of a boat.
The Encantados are magical river dolphins found in this South American river. They turn human at night in order to seduce and impregnate other humans.

bonuses.leadin: The Verneuil process is used to artificially produce this mineral. For 10 points each:
answers: corundum [prompt on BUT DO NOT REVEAL ruby or sapphire]
parts: Name this mineral which defines a hardness of 9 on the Mohs scale.

Generally, any corundum that does not have a red color is referred to as this gemstone, although this gemstone is traditionally blue. A common-type of laser contains this gemstone doped with titanium ions.
Just as corundum ranks highly on the Mohs scale of scratch hardness, it also ranks highly on the Vickers scale, which measures this kind of hardness.
answers_formatted: corundum [prompt on BUT DO NOT REVEAL ruby or sapphire]

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about the Greek explorer Pytheas. For 10 points each:
parts: Pytheas hailed from this Mediterranean port settled by colonists from the Anatolian city of Phocaea. This city competed with the Roman colony of Narbo Martius after the establishment of the province of Transalpine Gaul.
Pytheas traveled to this island and was the first to write its name, probably transliterating from the Welsh word for it. He described this island’s three corners as Kent, Cornwall, and Orkney.
Diodorus Siculus relates that Pytheas described the mining of this metal in Cornwall, which reached Europe by way of the port of Ictis and then down the Rhone River to Massalia.

bonuses.leadin: While working for this university, its most notable anthropologist gave a series of seminars open to missionaries and colonial officials headed to Africa. For 10 points each:
answers: London School of Economics and Political Science [or LSE]
parts: Name this university whose social anthropology department has had full-time faculty members like David Graeber, Maurice Bloch, Charles Gabriel Seligman, and Raymond Firth.

LSE endowed this man as the first Chair of Social Anthropology partly for his studies of people on islands off the coast of New Guinea. This Polish anthropologist is best-known for his book Argonauts of the Western Pacific.

E.E. Evans-Pritchard, a student of Malinowski, took a structural-functionalist approach in his works about this second most populous Nilotic ethnic group inhabiting South Sudan. They have recently been involved in civil wars with their fellow pastoralists, the Dinka.
answers_formatted: London School of Economics and Political Science [or LSE]
acceptable: London School of Economics and Political Science
London School of Economics and Political Science

bonuses.leadin: The protagonist of this novel criticizes her sibling for going on Instagram too much and playing “I Wanna Dance With Somebody” when she is supposed to be in mourning. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this Oyinkan Braithwaite novel, longlisted for the 2019 Booker Prize, in which the nurse Korede covers up the frequent murders of her younger sibling Ayoola.

Guyanan author E. R. Braithwaite is most famous for this autobiographical novel about an ex-RAF pilot who wins the respect of students in an East End school. This novel was made into a Sidney Poitier movie.
Kamau Braithwaite, a poet from Barbados, often uses customized, futuristic fonts in his “Sycorax video style,” named after the mother of Caliban from this work.
